item.title: Other countries have better sunscreens. Here's why we can't get them in the U.S.
item.description: Skin cancer is the most common cancer in the U.S. and we need all the protection we can get. So why is it so hard to get newer, more effective ingredients approved here?

item.title: These teens were missing too much school. Here's what it took to get them back
item.description: Since the pandemic, chronic absenteeism in the nation's K-12 schools has skyrocketed. These teens are working to get their attendance back on track.

item.title: In a debate over a school name, it's not just parents who are attached to the past
item.description: At the height of the racial reckoning, a school district in Virginia voted to rename two schools that had been previously named for Confederate generals. This month, that decision was reversed.

item.title: Arrested. Injured. Suspended. Six NYC university students say they'll keep protesting
item.description: Students arrested at Columbia University and the City College of New York spoke with NPR about their choice to risk legal and academic consequences.

item.title: Iowa superintendent and former Olympian bested in footrace by 5th grader
item.description: Ian Roberts has competed in some of the most high-profile races in the world. But his biggest competition to date was a determined 5th grader in jean shorts and Nike tennis shoes.

item.title: New York proposes a ban on guns that are easy to convert to illegal automatic weapons
item.description: Meanwhile, Maryland's governor signs a bill to address the surge of conversion devices, including Glock switches, that bypass a pistol's trigger mechanism, allowing the weapon to fire fully automatic.

item.title: Pete McCloskey's life reminds us how politics long in the past live on in the present
item.description: McCloskey's story has both deep roots and burgeoning relevance. He died this month at 96 and had long been out of the limelight, but the issues he had been willing to champion are as salient as ever.

item.title: Widespread power outages from deadly Houston storm raise new risk: hot weather
item.description: As the Houston area works to clean up and restore power to thousands after deadly storms, it will do so Saturday under a smog warning and as all of southern Texas starts to feel the heat.

item.title: Argentine president Javier Milei begins unusual visit to Spain, snubbing officials
item.description: Before kicking off a three-day visit to Madrid, Argentina's libertarian President Javier Milei stirred controversy, accusing the socialist government of bringing "poverty and death" to Spain.

item.title: Israel recovers the bodies of 3 hostages
item.description: The three were identified as Shani Louk, Amit Buskila and Yitzhak Gelernter. Israel's military said they had been killed by Hamas militants when they attacked a music festival on Oct. 7.
